
  * {
    -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
    box-sizing: border-box;
  }
  
  h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { font-weight: normal; }

  html {
    font-family: ProximaNova-Regular, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;
    max-width: 100vw !important;
  }

  body {
    color: #121416;
    margin: 0;
    font-size: 12px;
    background: #FFF;
    max-width: 100vw !important;
    -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;
  }

  .noScroll {
    overflow: hidden !important;
  }
  
  .noScrollIos {
    overflow: hidden;
    position: fixed;
    top: 0;
    left:0;
    width: 100%;
    height: 100%;
   }
   
   em {
     pointer-events: none;
   }
   
   a {
     pointer-events: all;
   }
   
   button, input {
     font-family: ProximaNova-Regular, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;
   }

   /* override ads elements that are added to the page */
   .cnx-resize-triggers {
      overflow: hidden;
   }

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Article","headline":"An Introduction To Charles Bukowski In 8 Poems","articleSection":"Los Angeles","description":"Get acquainted with the poet called the 'laureate of American lowlife' in these eight emblematic poems.","datePublished":"2016-08-22T23:47:59.000Z","datemodified":"2016-08-22T23:48:00Z","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https://theculturetrip.com/"},"image":{"@type":"imageObject","url":"https://cdn.theculturetrip.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/crumbbukowski_captain3-497x650.jpg","height":"574","width":"1024"},"publisher":{"@type":"Organization","name":"The Culture Trip","logo":{"@type":"imageObject","url":"https://cdn.theculturetrip.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/ct-horizontal_pmq_white.png"}},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Marnie Sehayek"}}Places To StayExperiencesTripsPlaces To StayExperiencesTripsTravel GuidesVideosMy PlansMy BookingsSign UpLog InTravel GuidesVideosBeyond HollywoodHungerlustPioneers of loveNORTH AMERICA/USA/CALIFORNIA/LOS ANGELES/BooksAn Introduction To Charles Bukowski In 8 PoemsR Crumb's illustration for Bukowski's book There's No Business. | © EccoMarnie Sehayek22 August 2016Add to PlanThe poems of prolific poet and author Charles Bukowski drudge through the mundane aspects of everyday life – work, life, relationships. But there is a bittersweet candidness to his observations that pull at the universal human condition, and that’s what continues to arrest readers today. In 1986, Time Magazine called Bukowski the ‘laureate of American lowlife.’ That may be true, but he’s also the laureate of Los Angeles, the city whose underbelly inspired the ethos of so many of his works. Read on to get acquainted with Bukowski on his own terms in these eight poems.‘The soldier, his wife and the bum’A dark narrative poem that speaks to two sad but shared inevitabilities – war and loneliness – in a thin-walled tenement in San Francisco. As he attempts to listen to the classics, he finds himself in inadvertent competition with an angry neighbor, a symbol of the enduring conflict of men. In this poem, Bukowski portrays himself as a bum but also intellectual, a trope that recurs throughout his work.war has its price and peace never lasts andmillions of young men everywhere would dieand as I listened to classical music I heard them making love, desperately andmournfully, through Shostakovich, Brahms,Mozart, through crescendo and climax, and through the sharedwall of our darkness.(31-38)‘The soldier, his wife and the bum.’ The Last Night of the Earth Poems. Ecco, 1992.‘The Laughing heart’This poem offers a glimmer of hope in self-determination in spite of life’s inevitable hardships. Bukowski is well known for his cynicism, lamenting the bleak and meaningless linear march of life. This poem is a counterpoint to that darkness; here, he speaks directly to the reader and implores us to take charge of our own destinies, not to actualize some grand life experience, but to find consolation in the drudgery – or better yet, to transcend it.your life is your lifedon’t let it be clubbed into dank submission.be on the watch.there are ways out.there is light somewhere.it may not be much light but it beats the darkness.(1-7)‘The Laughing Heart.’ The Laughing Heart. Black Sparrow Press, 1993.‘Bluebird’In this poem, Bukowski animates his vulnerability as a timid bluebird, one that he keeps behind his well-worn trappings of masculinity. He drowns the bird in whiskey and suppresses it with cigarette smoke, but it flits around inside of him nevertheless. The bluebird yearns to be seen candidly, but Bukowski is too inhibited to let it fly free. Bukowski’s self-conscious sensitivity is one of his most notable characteristics, softening the machismo so often found in his writing.There’s a bluebird in my heart thatwants to get out but I’m too tough for him,I say,stay down, do you want to messme up?you want to screw up theworks? you want to blow my book sales inEurope?(16-25)‘Bluebird.’ The Last Night of the Earth Poems. Ecco, 1992.‘Let It Enfold You’The poet recounts letting happiness in and how it’s important to let some things slide. Bukowski hilariously describes a time when he was more curmudgeonly, writing about his disdain for damn near everything, from ‘babies’ to ‘history,’ from ‘algebra’ to ‘flowers.’ His examples, innocuous to most people, exacerbate his ridiculous pessimism. He’s taking the piss out of himself. His self-awareness makes way for signature self-deprecation; in offering the reader a bit of wisdom from a lesson learned, Bukowski is still tethered by his misanthropic, browbeaten disposition.algebra angered meopera sickened me charlie chaplin was a fakeand flowers were for pansies.(40-45)‘Let It Enfold You.’ Betting on the Muse. Ecco, 1996.In a great, dark collaboration, R. Crumb illustrated Bukowski’s book Bring Me Your Love | © Black Sparrow Press‘Alone With Everybody’This bleak, existential treatise on the meaninglessness of life is classic Bukowski and offers insight into his characteristic cynicism. In this poem, the inevitability of death makes humanity’s search for meaning all for naught. All the while, we excrete detritus, from the garbage we throw away to the garbage of our own bodies that fill madhouses, hospitals, and ultimately graves. The vulgarity here is balanced by a deep sadness, a sensitivity. The solitude Bukowski describes here as a human condition is clearly deeply felt by the poet himself, resulting in this literary lashing out.the city dumps fillthe junkyards fill the madhouses fill the hospitals fill the graveyards fill nothing else fills.(27-33)‘Alone With Everybody’ Love is a Dog From Hell. Ecco, 1977.‘How Is Your Heart?’Bukowski talks of the certain and strange happiness brought on by the hard times. His self-reliance in this poem is consistent with his maladroit, tough guy persona. The poet recounts the rock-bottoms he regularly experienced with an irreverence and contentment. His dragging himself through the mud is, to some extent, voluntary, and in this poem, he self-congratulates as much as he pities himself. He revels in the freedom of down-and-outness and of having nothing at all to lose.to awaken in a cheap room in a strange city andpull up the shade-this was the craziest kind of contentment(27-31)‘How is your Heart?’ Ham on Rye. Ecco, 1982‘The sex fiends’Bukowski’s crass, misanthropic and drunken candor is well represented in this poem, which drips with dry humor and lasciviousness. The poem immediately begins with a parenthetical extension of the title: ‘we all are.’ The poet’s freewheeling perversity is borne from honesty. He’s cast off the chains of propriety and mores to experience the unadulterated if frowned upon realness of this life. In this poem, the pathologized sex addicts are merely the suckers seeking treatment for what Bukowski considers a human condition – one that he does not apologize for.well, the rabbit’s problem is that he propositions every woman he sees. he just walks up and asks them to go to bed with him.’ ‘I think that’s very honest,’ I said.‘Some very greasy characters use a roundabout approach.’(8-11)‘The sex fiends.’ Hearse, No. 17, 1972‘Air And Light And Time And Space’In this hard-nosed poem about creative motivation, Bukowski doesn’t coddle procrastinators and instead unforgivingly explains that there are no perfect conditions for creation. To fault an environment for inhibiting creativity is merely an excuse, he claims. If you’re going to make art, you’ll do it out of compulsion and passion, despite the fickle and ever-changing odds. This tough love is fitting for Bukowski, who proudly wrote in bars, brothels, and lousy tenements, from the underbelly of Los Angeles.baby, air and light and time and space have nothing to do with it and don’t create anythingexcept maybe a longer life to findnew excusesfor.(27-32)‘Air And Light And Time And Space.’ The Last Night of the Earth Poems. poems of prolific poet and author \u003ca href=\"https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/charles-bukowski\"\u003eCharles Bukowski\u003c/a\u003e drudge through the mundane aspects of everyday life – work, life, relationships. But there is a bittersweet candidness to his observations that pull at the universal human condition, and that’s what continues to arrest readers today. In 1986,\u003cem\u003e Time Magazine\u003c/em\u003e called Bukowski the ‘laureate of American lowlife.’ That may be true, but he’s also the laureate of \u003ca href=\"http://theculturetrip.com/north-america/california/los-angeles\"\u003eLos Angeles\u003c/a\u003e, the city whose underbelly inspired the ethos of so many of his works. Read on to get acquainted with Bukowski on his own terms in these eight poems."},{"type":"header","content":"‘The soldier, his wife and the bum’"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"A \u003ca href=\"https://www.poeticous.com/charles-bukowski/the-soldier-his-wife-and-the-bum\"\u003edark narrative poem\u003c/a\u003e that speaks to two sad but shared inevitabilities – war and loneliness – in a thin-walled tenement in \u003ca href=\"http://theculturetrip.com/north-america/california/san-francisco\"\u003eSan Francisco\u003c/a\u003e. As he attempts to listen to the classics, he finds himself in inadvertent competition with an angry neighbor, a symbol of the enduring conflict of men. Bukowski is well known for his cynicism, lamenting the bleak and meaningless linear march of life. This poem is a counterpoint to that darkness; here, he speaks directly to the reader and implores us to take charge of our own destinies, not to actualize some grand life experience, but to find consolation in the drudgery – or better yet, to transcend it."},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eyour life is your life\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003edon’t let it be clubbed into dank submission.\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003ebe on the watch.\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003ethere are ways out.\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003ethere is light somewhere.\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eit may not be much light but\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003e it beats the darkness.\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"(1-7)"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"‘The Laughing Heart.’ \u003cem\u003eThe Laughing Heart.\u003c/em\u003e Black Sparrow Press, 1993."},{"type":"frame","src":"https://www.youtube.com/embed/DhM-Dm2PHHo?feature=oembed","width":"500","height":"375"},{"type":"header","content":"‘Bluebird’"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"In \u003ca href=\"https://allpoetry.com/poem/8509539-Bluebird-by-Charles-Bukowski\"\u003ethis poem\u003c/a\u003e, Bukowski animates his vulnerability as a timid bluebird, one that he keeps behind his well-worn trappings of masculinity. He drowns the bird in whiskey and suppresses it with cigarette smoke, but it flits around inside of him nevertheless. The bluebird yearns to be seen candidly, but Bukowski is too inhibited to let it fly free. Bukowski’s self-conscious sensitivity is one of his most notable characteristics, softening the machismo so often found in his writing."},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eThere’s a bluebird in my heart that\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003ewants to get out \u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003ebut I’m too tough for him,\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eI say,\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003estay down, do you want to mess\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eme up?\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eyou want to screw up the\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eworks?\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003e you want to blow my book sales in\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eEurope?\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"(16-25)"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"‘Bluebird.’ \u003cem\u003eThe Last Night of the Earth Poems. \u003c/em\u003eEcco, 1992."},{"type":"header","content":"‘Let It Enfold You’"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"The poet \u003ca href=\"http://www.poemhunter.com/poem/let-it-enfold-you/\"\u003erecounts\u003c/a\u003e letting happiness in and how it’s important to let some things slide. Bukowski hilariously describes a time when he was more curmudgeonly, writing about his disdain for damn near everything, from ‘babies’ to ‘history,’ from ‘algebra’ to ‘flowers.’ His examples, innocuous to most people, exacerbate his ridiculous pessimism. He’s taking the piss out of himself. His self-awareness makes way for signature self-deprecation; in offering the reader a bit of wisdom from a lesson learned, Bukowski is still tethered by his misanthropic, browbeaten disposition."},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003ealgebra angered me\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eopera sickened me \u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003echarlie chaplin was a\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003e fake\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003eand flowers were for \u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003epansies.\u003c/em\u003e"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"(40-45)"},{"type":"paragraph","tag":"p","content":"\u003cem\u003e‘\u003c/em\u003eLet It Enfold You.’ \u003cem\u003eBetting on the Muse\u003c/em\u003e.
